name: Outpatient SOAP (Paragraph)
description: Standard outpatient visit with paragraph-style HPI - Primary Care
content:
SUBJECTIVE:
Patient is a 45-year-old male presenting with 3 days of right knee pain. He states it started after playing tennis. The pain is sharp, 6/10, worse with walking, better with rest. No swelling or redness noted. He has tried Ibuprofen with some relief. Denies fevers or chills.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 130/80, HR 72, Temp 98.6.
Gen: NAD.
MSK: Right knee with mild tenderness over medial joint line. McMurray's negative. Lachman's negative. ROM intact but painful at end flexion. No effusion.

ASSESSMENT:
Right knee pain, likely medial meniscus strain vs sprain.

PLAN:
1. Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation.
2. Continue NSAIDs prn.
3. Return if worse or no improvement in 1 week.

name: Hospital Admission (Bulleted)
description: Inpatient admission with bulleted HPI - Internal Medicine
content:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient is a 68-year-old female with PMH of CHF, COPD, and Diabetes who presents with shortness of breath.

*   Onset: 2 days ago, gradual worsening.
*   Severity: Now dyspneic at rest.
*   Associated Sx: Orthopnea (3 pillows), PND, and increased leg swelling.
*   Triggers: None identified. No missed meds.
*   ROS: Positive for cough (dry), negative for fever, chest pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Const: Fatigue.
Resp: SOB, Cough.
CV: Leg swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Gen: Sitting upright, tachypneic.
Lungs: Crackles bilateral bases halfway up. Wheezing expiratory.
Heart: RRR, S3 gallop present. 2+ pitting edema to knees.

LABS/IMAGING:
Na 135, K 4.5, Cr 1.2 (baseline 1.0).
BNP: 1200.
CXR: Pulmonary edema, cardiomegaly.

ASSESSMENT/PLAN:
1. Acute Decompensated Heart Failure
   - Likely due to dietary indiscretion.
   - Start Lasix 40mg IV BID.
   - Monitor I/Os, daily weights.
2. COPD Exacerbation
   - Mild wheezing, likely reactive.
   - Cont Duonebs.
3. Diabetes Type 2
   - SSI.

name: Pediatric Well-Child (Structured)
description: Well-child check with growth chart data - Pediatrics
content:
WELL CHILD CHECK - 2 YEARS

CHIEF CONCERN: None. Here for 2-year checkup.

HISTORY:
- Development: Walking well, running. Says 20+ words. Starting 2-word phrases.
- Diet: Whole milk 16oz/day. Eats table foods. No choking episodes.
- Sleep: 11 hours at night, 2-hour nap.
- Safety: Car seat rear-facing. Outlet covers in place.

GROWTH:
Weight: 12.5 kg (50th percentile)
Height: 86 cm (60th percentile)
Head Circ: 48 cm (50th percentile)

EXAM:
Gen: Alert, playful, appropriate.
HEENT: TMs clear bilaterally. Dentition: 16 teeth.
Heart: RRR, no murmur.
Lungs: Clear.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.
Neuro: Walks independently, climbs stairs with hand held.

ASSESSMENT:
Healthy 2-year-old. Development appropriate.

PLAN:
- Vaccines: DTaP, IPV, Hib, PCV13 given today.
- Anticipatory guidance: Discipline, screen time limits.
- RTC: 3-year visit.

name: Cardiology Consult (Focused)
description: Specialist consult with specific question - Cardiology
content:
REASON FOR CONSULT: Pre-operative cardiac risk stratification.

HISTORY:
Mr. Jones is a 72M scheduled for elective total hip arthroplasty tomorrow. He reports good functional capacity - can walk 2 blocks and climb 1 flight of stairs without chest pain or SOB. 

PMH: HTN, HLD.
MEDS: Lisinopril, Atorvastatin.
ALLERGIES: PCN.

EXAM:
BP 140/85, HR 68.
Heart: Regular rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Clear.
Ext: No edema.

EKG:
NSR at 68 bpm. No Q waves or ST changes.

IMPRESSION:
72M with RCRI score 0. Good functional capacity (>4 METs).

RECOMMENDATION:
Low cardiac risk for non-cardiac surgery.
Proceed with surgery.
Continue beta-blocker if started (none currently).
No further cardiac testing indicated.

name: Voice Dictation (Unstructured)
description: Raw dictation simulating voice-to-text - Family Medicine
content: Patient is here for follow up of hypertension. Uh, blood pressure today was 150 over 90. He says he missed a few doses of his lisinopril because he ran out. No chest pain or shortness of breath. Exam is normal heart sounds regular lungs clear. I'm gonna refill his lisinopril 20 milligrams daily and told him to take it every day. Also checked a chem 7 which was normal. Potassium 4.2. Creatinine 0.9. Follow up in 3 months.

name: Psychiatric Intake (Narrative)
content:
PSYCHIATRIC INTAKE EVALUATION

IDENTIFYING INFORMATION:
28-year-old female presenting for initial evaluation of depression.

CHIEF COMPLAINT:
"I can't get out of bed anymore."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient reports 6 months of worsening depressed mood. She describes feeling sad most days, with decreased interest in activities she used to enjoy (reading, seeing friends). Sleep is increased - sleeping 12 hours per day but still feels tired. Appetite is decreased with 10-lb unintentional weight loss. Concentration is poor at work. Denies suicidal ideation currently, but reports passive thoughts of "not wanting to be here" 2 weeks ago. No plan or intent. No prior suicide attempts.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY:
One prior episode of depression at age 22 during college, treated with Zoloft for 1 year with good response. Discontinued after feeling better.

MENTAL STATUS EXAM:
Appearance: Casually dressed, poor eye contact.
Behavior: Psychomotor slowing noted.
Speech: Soft, decreased rate.
Mood: "Terrible."
Affect: Flat, congruent.
Thought Process: Linear, goal-directed.
Thought Content: Denies SI/HI currently. No delusions.
Perception: No hallucinations.
Cognition: Alert and oriented x3. Concentration impaired.
Insight: Good - recognizes need for treatment.
Judgment: Fair.

ASSESSMENT:
Major Depressive Disorder, recurrent episode, moderate severity.

PLAN:
1. Restart Sertraline 50mg daily.
2. Refer to therapy (CBT).
3. Safety plan reviewed. Patient to call crisis line if SI worsens.
4. Follow-up in 2 weeks.

name: OB Prenatal Visit (Templated)
description: Routine prenatal visit with template format - Obstetrics
content:
OB VISIT - 28 WEEKS

GRAVIDA/PARA: G2P1001
EDD: 12/15/2024 (by LMP, confirmed by US)
GESTATIONAL AGE: 28w0d

INTERVAL HISTORY:
- Fetal movement: Good, feels baby move throughout day.
- Contractions: None.
- Vaginal bleeding: None.
- Leakage of fluid: None.
- Concerns: None.

VITALS:
BP: 118/72
Weight: +18 lbs from pre-pregnancy weight

EXAM:
Fundal Height: 28 cm (appropriate for dates)
FHR: 145 bpm by Doppler
Edema: Trace pedal edema

LABS TODAY:
- Glucose screen (1-hour): 128 (normal <140)
- Hemoglobin: 11.2 (mild anemia)

ASSESSMENT:
Intrauterine pregnancy at 28 weeks. Uncomplicated.

PLAN:
- Continue prenatal vitamins.
- Start iron supplementation for mild anemia.
- Tdap vaccine given today.
- RhoGAM given (patient is Rh negative).
- Return in 2 weeks for routine visit.
- Discussed signs of preterm labor.

name: ED Trauma Note (ATLS Format)
description: Emergency department trauma evaluation - Emergency Medicine
content:
TRAUMA ACTIVATION - LEVEL 2

MECHANISM: MVC, T-boned on driver side at ~35 mph. Airbags deployed. Prolonged extrication.

PRIMARY SURVEY:
A: Airway patent, C-spine immobilized.
B: RR 20, SpO2 98% on RA. Breath sounds equal bilaterally.
C: HR 110, BP 100/60. 2 large-bore IVs placed. 1L NS bolus given.
D: GCS 15 (E4V5M6). Pupils 3mm, equal and reactive.
E: Temp 98.2. No obvious deformities. Abrasions to left chest wall.

SECONDARY SURVEY:
HEAD: No step-offs, no hematoma.
NECK: Midline, no tenderness. C-collar in place.
CHEST: Tenderness over left ribs 5-7. No crepitus.
ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender. Seatbelt sign present.
PELVIS: Stable.
EXTREMITIES: No deformities. Pulses intact x4.

IMAGING:
- CT Head: Negative for bleed.
- CT C-spine: No fracture.
- CXR: Left rib fractures 5-6, no pneumothorax.
- CT Abdomen/Pelvis: No solid organ injury. No free fluid.

ASSESSMENT:
Blunt chest trauma with rib fractures. Hemodynamically stable.

DISPOSITION:
Admit to Trauma Surgery for pain control and pulmonary toilet.
Incentive spirometry.
Pain control: Toradol, Tylenol. Avoid NSAIDs long-term given rib fx.

name: Dermatology Progress Note (Problem-Focused)
description: Follow-up for chronic skin condition - Dermatology
content:
DERMATOLOGY FOLLOW-UP

PROBLEM: Moderate plaque psoriasis

HPI:
Patient returns for 3-month follow-up of psoriasis. Started on Otezla 3 months ago after failing topical therapies. Reports significant improvement in plaques on elbows and knees. Itching much better. No side effects from medication. Compliance is good.

EXAM:
Elbows: Previously thick, scaly plaques now with minimal erythema and scaling. Estimated 80% improvement.
Knees: Similar improvement.
Scalp: Mild scaling, improved from baseline.

BSA affected: <3% (down from 15% at last visit)
PASI score: 4.2 (down from 18.5)

ASSESSMENT:
Moderate plaque psoriasis, well-controlled on Otezla.

PLAN:
- Continue Otezla 30mg BID.
- Continue clobetasol foam to scalp PRN.
- Labs: CBC, CMP today to monitor (patient on Otezla >3 months).
- RTC in 6 months or sooner if flare.

name: Operative Note (Structured)
content:
OPERATIVE REPORT

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Acute appendicitis
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Acute appendicitis, perforated
PROCEDURE: Laparoscopic appendectomy
SURGEON: Dr. Smith
ASSISTANT: Dr. Jones
ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal

INDICATION:
32-year-old male with 24 hours of RLQ pain, fever, and elevated WBC. CT showed inflamed appendix with surrounding fat stranding.

FINDINGS:
Perforated appendix at tip with purulent fluid in RLQ. No abscess formation.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
Patient positioned supine. Timeout performed. Abdomen prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Umbilical incision made and Veress needle inserted. Pneumoperitoneum established to 15mmHg. 10mm trocar placed at umbilicus under direct vision. Two 5mm trocars placed in LLQ and suprapubic region under direct visualization.

Appendix identified in RLQ. Purulent fluid noted and suctioned. Appendix mobilized. Mesoappendix divided with LigaSure. Appendiceal base stapled with Endo-GIA. Appendix placed in specimen bag and removed through umbilical port. Irrigation of RLQ performed with 1L warm saline until clear. Hemostasis confirmed. Trocars removed under direct vision. Fascia at umbilicus closed with 0-Vicryl. Skin closed with 4-0 Monocryl subcuticular.

EBL: <10mL
SPECIMEN: Appendix to pathology
COMPLICATIONS: None
DISPOSITION: To PACU in stable condition
